tutorial.title: Interacting with Webpages
tutorial.descriptionContent: Learn how to make JavaScript and HTML work together.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent: Behind every dynamic website, there's some JavaScript code. On this webpage, JavaScript changes the text when you click the reverse button.

lessons.title: Including JavaScript
lessons.interactiveContent:
To add JavaScript code to a webpage, we start with the <script> and </script> tags.

Make sure to pick <script>, followed by </script>.

lessons.title: Including JavaScript
lessons.interactiveContent:
The script element is the last element before the closing </body> tag in the HTML structure.

Make sure to pick <h3>Tweeter, followed by </h3>, and finally <script>.

lessons.title: Including JavaScript
lessons.interactiveContent:
Similar to CSS, we use a separate file to write JavaScript. To do this, we include a src attribute that links to the file we want to use.

Make sure to pick src, followed by =, and finally "script.js".

lessons.title: Including JavaScript
lessons.interactiveContent:
In the JS file, we can write JavaScript like const username = "Lee";.

Make sure to pick const, followed by username, and finally "Lee".

lessons.title: Running
lessons.interactiveContent:
The JavaScript runs automatically when the webpage displays. Find the output of console.log(username) in the Output tab.

Make sure to pick username, followed by username.

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which tags do we use to add JavaScript code to HTML?

<script> and </script><style> and <style>

<script> and </script>.

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Where in the HTML structure do we add the script element?

In the last position in the body elementAnywhere in the body element

In the last position in the body element.

lessons.title: Question 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Where does the JavaScript code go?

Inside the JavaScript fileAnywhere inside the body element

Inside the JavaScript file.

lessons.title: Question 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we run the code in the JavaScript file linked via the script element?

It runs automatically when the webpage displaysWe have to add a special instruction

It runs automatically when the webpage displays.

lessons.title: Example 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the opening script tag.

Make sure to pick < followed by script and then src="script.js", >, </script>.

lessons.title: Example 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Insert the elements in their correct positions.

Make sure to pick <script src="script.js"></script>, followed by </body>.

lessons.title: Example 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Link to script.js using the src attribute.

Make sure to type src="script.js".

lessons.title: Example 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Display the sum of the level1 and level2 variables.

Make sure to pick console, followed by log, and finally +.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent: We've seen how we can add JavaScript to our HTML files. Now let's use the script tags to interact with HTML elements.

lessons.title: Identify the Elements
lessons.interactiveContent:
To tell the elements how to respond to, say, a button click, we need to identify them.

To identify the elements we want to interact with, we can give each of them a unique id. Let's add an ID to the p element.

Make sure to pick id, followed by =, and finally "secret".

lessons.title: Accessing an Element
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can access the HTML elements of our webpage using the document keyword. document represents our webpage.

Now, to interact with an HTML element, we need the document.getElementById() instruction.

Make sure to pick document, followed by getElementById.

lessons.title: Accessing by ID
lessons.interactiveContent:
Inside document.getElementById() we place the ID of the element we want to interact with, like secret here.

Make sure to pick document followed by getElementById and then (, "secret", ).

lessons.title: onclick
lessons.interactiveContent:
Interactive webpages often use buttons to react to clicks from visitors.

However, without more information, a button tag is useless. To react to clicks from visitors, a button tag needs the onclick attribute.

Make sure to pick onclick.

lessons.title: Function call
lessons.interactiveContent:
The onclick attribute can call functions when a visitor clicks on the button. Set onclick to "show()".

In this function, we can add the code to trigger the behavior we want. Check script.js to see the function the button will call.

Make sure to pick =, followed by "show()".

lessons.title: Accessing Text
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use the show function to change the content of an element, like its text, when we click a button.

First, access the text of the p with the innerHTML instruction.

Make sure to pick ., followed by innerHTML.

lessons.title: Setting text
lessons.interactiveContent:
Now that we have accessed the text of the p element, we can change it.

Set the text of the p element to "not telling you!".

Make sure to pick =, followed by "not telling you!".

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which instruction do we use to access an element?

document.getElementById()getElementById()

Make sure to pick document.getElementById().

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What can we use IDs for?

To identify HTML elements and interact with them using JavaScriptTo display similar elements

To identify HTML elements and interact with them using JavaScript.

lessons.title: Question 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which instruction accesses the paragraph?

document.getElementById("explore")document.getElementById("tours")

Make sure to pick document.getElementById("explore").

lessons.title: Question 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which attribute retrieves the text of an HTML element?

.innerHTML.text

Make sure to pick .innerHTML.

lessons.title: Question 5
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's the text of the paragraph after the button is clicked?

First week is on usTry the free trial

First week is on us.

lessons.title: Question 6
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this code?

None of the HTML elements has an id called favoriteinnerHTMLshould be INNERhtml

None of the HTML elements has an id called favorite.

lessons.title: Question 7
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the onclick attribute do?

It defines what happens when visitors click a buttonIt takes visitors to another website

It defines what happens when visitors click a button.

lessons.title: Example 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Upon clicking on the Magic button, change the bike rental's owner by updating the heading's text.

Make sure to pick document.getElementById("rental") followed by .innerHTML and then =, "Ron's Bike Rental".

lessons.title: Example 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add the attribute to react to clicks from visitors.

Make sure to pick onclick.

lessons.title: Example 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set the value of the onclick attribute to call the deleteAccount function when a visitor clicks on the button.

Make sure to pick "deleteAccount()".
